rev.comment: /* Deaths */ Gonna move to the protest section, chill

Line 178: Line 178:
Leading up to the protests, at least six cases of [[self-immolation]] were reported, including a man arrested while trying to set himself on fire in downtown [[Cairo]].<ref name="Self-Immolation Spreads Across the Mideast">{{cite web|author=Rosenberg, David|url=http://www.themedialine.org/news/news_detail.asp?NewsID=31194|title=Self-Immolation Spreads Across the Mideast, Inspiring Protest, Controversy|publisher=[[The Media Line]]|date=24 January 2011 |accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> These cases were inspired by, and began exactly one month after, the acts of self-immolation in Tunisia triggering the [[2010â2011 Tunisian uprising]]. Six instances have been reported, including acts by Abdou Abdel-Moneim Jaafar,<ref name="Abdou Abdel-Moneim">{{ar}}{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/7F5D64C8-241F-4F34-B36A-4F259CBF3371.htm?GoogleStatID=20|title=ÙØµØ±Ù ÙØ­Ø±Ù ÙÙØ³Ù Ø£ÙØ§Ù Ø§ÙØ¨Ø±ÙÙØ§Ù|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=17 January 2011 |accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> Mohammed Farouk Hassan,<ref name="Mohammed Farouk Hassan">{{cite web|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE70H3L720110118|title=Egyptians set themselves ablaze after Tunisia unrest|author=Zayed, Dina|date=18 January 2011 |work=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> Mohammed Ashour Sorour,<ref>{{ar}}{{cite web|url=http://www.elaosboa.com/show.asp?id=20522&vnum=fesal&page=mahalyat|title=ÙÙØ¸Ù Ø¨Ù'ÙØµØ± ÙÙØ·ÙØ±Ø§Ù' ÙÙØ¯Ø¯ Ø¨Ø­Ø±Ù ÙÙØ³Ù Ø£ÙØ§Ù ÙÙØ§Ø¨Ø© Ø§ÙØµØ­ÙÙÙÙ|author=|date=18 January 2011 |work=|publisher=El-Aosboa Newspaper|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> and Ahmed Hashim al-Sayyed who later died from his injuries.<ref name="Ahmed Hashim El-Sayyid2">{{cite web|url=http://news.yahoo.com/nphotos/slideshow/photo//110118/ids_photos_wl/r3428700330.jpg/|title=Mother of Ahmed Hashim al-Sayyed|author=|date=18 January 2011 |work=[[Yahoo! News]]|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref>
Leading up to the protests, at least six cases of [[self-immolation]] were reported, including a man arrested while trying to set himself on fire in downtown [[Cairo]].<ref name="Self-Immolation Spreads Across the Mideast">{{cite web|author=Rosenberg, David|url=http://www.themedialine.org/news/news_detail.asp?NewsID=31194|title=Self-Immolation Spreads Across the Mideast, Inspiring Protest, Controversy|publisher=[[The Media Line]]|date=24 January 2011 |accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> These cases were inspired by, and began exactly one month after, the acts of self-immolation in Tunisia triggering the [[2010â2011 Tunisian uprising]]. Six instances have been reported, including acts by Abdou Abdel-Moneim Jaafar,<ref name="Abdou Abdel-Moneim">{{ar}}{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/7F5D64C8-241F-4F34-B36A-4F259CBF3371.htm?GoogleStatID=20|title=ÙØµØ±Ù ÙØ­Ø±Ù ÙÙØ³Ù Ø£ÙØ§Ù Ø§ÙØ¨Ø±ÙÙØ§Ù|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=17 January 2011 |accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> Mohammed Farouk Hassan,<ref name="Mohammed Farouk Hassan">{{cite web|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE70H3L720110118|title=Egyptians set themselves ablaze after Tunisia unrest|author=Zayed, Dina|date=18 January 2011 |work=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> Mohammed Ashour Sorour,<ref>{{ar}}{{cite web|url=http://www.elaosboa.com/show.asp?id=20522&vnum=fesal&page=mahalyat|title=ÙÙØ¸Ù Ø¨Ù'ÙØµØ± ÙÙØ·ÙØ±Ø§Ù' ÙÙØ¯Ø¯ Ø¨Ø­Ø±Ù ÙÙØ³Ù Ø£ÙØ§Ù ÙÙØ§Ø¨Ø© Ø§ÙØµØ­ÙÙÙÙ|author=|date=18 January 2011 |work=|publisher=El-Aosboa Newspaper|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> and Ahmed Hashim al-Sayyed who later died from his injuries.<ref name="Ahmed Hashim El-Sayyid2">{{cite web|url=http://news.yahoo.com/nphotos/slideshow/photo//110118/ids_photos_wl/r3428700330.jpg/|title=Mother of Ahmed Hashim al-Sayyed|author=|date=18 January 2011 |work=[[Yahoo! News]]|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref>
â
The death toll from the violence had risen to 54 dead and 1,000 injured by 28 January.<ref name="asianews1"/> As of 29 January, at least 102<ref name=autogenerated2 /><ref name=sky-2011-01-30 /> to 105 people were known to have died, many or most of them shot, based on body counts at morgues.<ref name=AlJazeera29th1pm/> The dead including 10 policemen, 3 of whom were killed in [[Rafah]].<ref name=autogenerated2 /> The city of Suez has seen the most violence of the protests thus far. Eyewitness reports have suggested that the death toll there may be higher, although confirmation has been difficult due to a ban on media coverage in the area.<ref name="rawstory.com">{{cite web|last=Tencer |first=Daniel |url=http://www.rawstory.com/rs/2011/01/reports-massacre-suez-protests-egypt/ |title=Reports of âmassacreâ in Suez as protests in Egypt move into third day |publisher=Raw Story |date=14 January 2011 |accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref> Some online activists have referred to Suez as Egypt's [[Sidi Bouzid]], the Tunisian city where protests started.<ref>{{cite news|last=Dziadosz|first=Alexander|title=Could Suez be Egypt's Sidi Bouzid?|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE70Q1KZ20110127|accessdate=29 January 2011|work=[[Reuters]]|date=27 January 2011}}</ref>
+
The death toll from the violence had risen to 54 dead and 1,000 injured by 28 January.<ref name="asianews1"/> As of 29 January, at least 102<ref name=autogenerated2 /><ref name=sky-2011-01-30 /> to 105 people were known to have died, many or most of them shot, based on body counts at morgues.<ref name=AlJazeera29th1pm/> The dead including 10 policemen, 3 of whom were killed in [[Rafah]].<ref name=autogenerated2 />
By 30 January At least 102 people had been killed and 2,000 injured since protests began, according to security and medical reports.<<REF16>><ref name=sky-2011-01-30 /> Funerals for the dead on the "Friday of Anger" were held on 30 January.<!--from tv--> Hundreds of mourners gathered for the funerals calling for Mubarak's removal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/01/2011129171519806580.html |title=Hundreds Mourn the Dead in Egypt â Middle East |work=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date= |accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref>
By 30 January At least 102 people had been killed and 2,000 injured since protests began, according to security and medical reports.<<REF16>><ref name=sky-2011-01-30 /> Funerals for the dead on the "Friday of Anger" were held on 30 January.<!--from tv--> Hundreds of mourners gathered for the funerals calling for Mubarak's removal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/01/2011129171519806580.html |title=Hundreds Mourn the Dead in Egypt â Middle East |work=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date= |accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref>
